title: JKSSB JE (Civil) Exam: Core Engineering Mechanics & Structural Analysis Assessment
description: This professional assessment is meticulously designed for aspirants of the JKSSB Junior Engineer (Civil) recruitment examination. It provides a rigorous evaluation of core principles in Engineering Mechanics and Structural Analysis, aligning with undergraduate curriculum standards and the specific format of the JKSSB exam. The test features a blend of conceptual and practical questions covering essential topics, including: Laws of Force and equilibrium conditions ($\sum F = 0$), principles of Moment ($\sum M = 0$), concepts of static and kinetic Friction, and the calculation of Centre of Gravity. Successfully completing this test will strengthen your foundational knowledge and problem-solving skills, crucial for excelling in the competitive examination.

questions.text: Two forces of 80 N and 100 N are acting at a point such that the angle between them is 60°. The magnitude of the resultant force is approximately:
questions.explanation: The magnitude of the resultant force (R) is found using the Parallelogram Law of Forces: $R = \sqrt{P^2 + Q^2 + 2PQ \cos\theta}$. Here, P = 80 N, Q = 100 N, and $\theta = 60°$. So, $R = \sqrt{80^2 + 100^2 + 2(80)(100)\cos(60°)} = \sqrt{6400 + 10000 + 16000(0.5)} = \sqrt{16400 + 8000} = \sqrt{24400} \approx 156.2$ N.

questions.text: Lami's theorem can be applied to a system of forces only if the forces are:

options.text: Any three forces regardless of their orientation

questions.explanation: Lami's theorem is a special case of the sine rule for a triangle of forces. It is applicable only to a system of three forces that are coplanar (in the same plane), concurrent (acting at the same point), and in equilibrium.

questions.text: A block weighing 200 N is placed on a rough horizontal surface. If the coefficient of static friction is 0.3, the magnitude of the frictional force when a horizontal force of 50 N is applied to the block is:
questions.explanation: First, calculate the limiting (maximum) static friction: $F_{lim} = \mu_s \times N = 0.3 \times 200\ N = 60$ N. Since the applied force (50 N) is less than the limiting friction (60 N), the block will not move. The static frictional force developed is self-adjusting and will be equal and opposite to the applied force. Therefore, the frictional force is 50 N.

questions.text: According to Varignon's Theorem, the algebraic sum of the moments of a system of coplanar forces about a point is equal to:

options.text: Zero, only if the system is in equilibrium
The moment of their resultant force about the same point
The product of the resultant force and the number of forces

questions.explanation: Varignon's Theorem, or the principle of moments, states that the moment of a resultant of a system of forces about any point is equal to the algebraic sum of the moments of its individual component forces about the same point.

questions.text: A body is on the verge of sliding down a rough inclined plane when the angle of inclination is 30°. The coefficient of static friction is:
questions.explanation: The angle at which a body is on the verge of sliding down an inclined plane under its own weight is called the angle of repose ($\alpha$). This angle is equal to the angle of friction ($\phi$). The coefficient of static friction ($\mu_s$) is given by the tangent of the angle of friction. Therefore, $\mu_s = \tan(\phi) = \tan(\alpha) = \tan(30°) = 1/\sqrt{3} \approx 0.577$.

questions.text: A couple is formed by two forces, each of magnitude F, separated by a perpendicular distance 'd'. The moment of the couple is independent of:

options.text: The point about which the moment is taken

questions.explanation: A couple produces a pure turning effect. Its moment is calculated as M = F × d. A key property of a couple is that its moment is the same about any point in its plane. It is a 'free vector'.

questions.text: A simply supported beam of span 6 m is subjected to a point load of 30 kN at its center. The reaction at each support is:
questions.explanation: For a simply supported beam with a central point load, the load is shared equally by the two supports due to symmetry. Alternatively, using the equilibrium equation $\Sigma F_y = 0$, we have $R_A + R_B = 30$ kN. Taking moments about support A ($\Sigma M_A = 0$), we get $R_B \times 6 - 30 \times 3 = 0$, which gives $R_B = 90/6 = 15$ kN. Therefore, $R_A = 30 - 15 = 15$ kN.

questions.text: Which statement correctly describes the relationship between static friction ($f_s$), limiting friction ($f_{lim}$), and kinetic friction ($f_k$)?
questions.explanation: Static friction ($f_s$) is a self-adjusting force that opposes impending motion, and its value is always less than or equal to the limiting friction ($f_{lim}$). Limiting friction is the maximum possible static friction. Kinetic friction ($f_k$) is the friction that acts when the body is in motion, and it is generally less than the limiting friction.

questions.text: A 100 N force is to be resolved into two components along lines making angles of 30° and 45° on opposite sides of the force. The magnitude of the component along the 45° line will be:
questions.explanation: Using the Sine Rule on the triangle of forces. Let F1 be the component along the 30° line and F2 along the 45° line. The angle opposite F1 is 45°, opposite F2 is 30°, and opposite the 100 N force is $180° - (30° + 45°) = 105°$. So, $\frac{F2}{\sin(30°)} = \frac{100}{\sin(105°)}$. Thus, $F2 = \frac{100 \times \sin(30°)}{\sin(105°)} = \frac{100 \times 0.5}{0.9659} \approx 51.8$ N.

questions.text: A ladder is resting against a smooth vertical wall and a rough horizontal floor. The ladder is more likely to slip when a person:

options.text: Stands at the bottom of the ladder
Stands in the middle of the ladder
Stands at the top of the ladder
The position of the person does not affect stability

questions.explanation: When the person climbs higher, their weight creates a larger clockwise moment about the base of the ladder. To maintain equilibrium, the counter-clockwise moment from the wall's reaction force must increase. This requires a larger horizontal reaction at the wall, which in turn requires a larger frictional force at the floor. The ladder slips when this required frictional force exceeds the limiting friction.

questions.text: A point is in equilibrium under the action of three forces. The magnitudes of two forces are 6 N and 8 N, and the angle between them is 90°. The magnitude of the third force is:
questions.explanation: For the point to be in equilibrium, the third force must be equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the resultant of the other two forces. The resultant (R) of the 6 N and 8 N forces at 90° is $R = \sqrt{6^2 + 8^2} = \sqrt{36 + 64} = \sqrt{100} = 10$ N. Therefore, the third force must have a magnitude of 10 N.

questions.text: The principle of transmissibility states that the effect of a force on a rigid body remains unchanged if:

options.text: The force is replaced by a couple of the same moment
The force is moved to any point on the body
The force is moved to any other point along its line of action
The direction of the force is reversed

questions.explanation: The principle of transmissibility is a fundamental concept in statics of rigid bodies. It states that the external effect of a force on a rigid body is the same for all points of application along its line of action.

questions.text: A force F = (4i + 3j) N acts at a point having a position vector r = (2i + j) m from the origin. The moment of the force about the origin is:
questions.explanation: The moment M is calculated by the cross product of the position vector r and the force vector F, i.e., M = r x F. $M = (2i + j) \times (4i + 3j)$. The cross product in 2D is given by $(r_x F_y - r_y F_x)k$. So, M = $((2)(3) - (1)(4))k = (6 - 4)k = 2k$ N-m. The option -2k N-m would be correct if the cross product was calculated as F x r.

questions.text: The resultant of two equal forces P is also equal to P. The angle between the two forces is:
questions.explanation: The formula for the resultant R of two forces P and Q at an angle $\theta$ is $R^2 = P^2 + Q^2 + 2PQ\cos\theta$. Given R = P and Q = P. The equation becomes $P^2 = P^2 + P^2 + 2P(P)\cos\theta$. Simplifying, $P^2 = 2P^2 + 2P^2\cos\theta$. This leads to $-P^2 = 2P^2\cos\theta$. So, $\cos\theta = -1/2$. The angle $\theta$ for which $\cos\theta = -1/2$ is 120°.

questions.text: The frictional force is always a:
questions.explanation: Frictional force is a passive or reactive force. It comes into play only when there is an applied force or a tendency of motion. It reacts to oppose the motion or the tendency of motion, and its magnitude adjusts itself up to a certain limit (limiting friction).

questions.text: A block of weight W is placed on a rough inclined plane with an angle of inclination $\alpha$. If the angle of friction is $\phi$, the condition for the block to be in equilibrium (not sliding down) is:
questions.explanation: The block will start sliding down when the component of its weight along the plane ($W\sin\alpha$) overcomes the maximum frictional force ($\mu N = \mu W\cos\alpha$). The condition for impending motion is $\tan\alpha = \mu = \tan\phi$, so $\alpha = \phi$. For the block to remain in equilibrium and not slide down, the angle of inclination $\alpha$ must be less than or equal to the angle of friction $\phi$.

questions.text: It is generally easier to pull a heavy object than to push it because:

options.text: Pushing increases the coefficient of friction.
Pulling at an angle has a vertical component that reduces the normal reaction.
The line of action of the force is lower when pushing.
Pulling at an angle has a vertical component that increases the normal reaction.

questions.explanation: When an object is pulled at an upward angle, the force has a vertical component that acts upwards. This reduces the net downward force on the ground, thereby reducing the normal reaction (N). Since frictional force is proportional to the normal reaction ($F_f = \mu N$), a smaller normal reaction results in less friction. Conversely, pushing at a downward angle increases the normal reaction and thus the friction.

questions.text: For a statically determinate pin-jointed plane truss, the relationship between the number of members (m) and the number of joints (j) is:
questions.explanation: For a plane truss to be statically determinate and stable, the number of members (m) must be related to the number of joints (j) by the equation m = 2j - 3. This equation ensures that there are exactly enough members to constrain all degrees of freedom of the joints without being redundant.

questions.text: A force of 50 N is applied to the end of a spanner of length 20 cm to tighten a nut. To produce the maximum turning moment, the force should be applied:

options.text: At any angle, as the moment is constant

questions.explanation: The moment (or torque) is calculated as $M = F \times d$, where d is the perpendicular distance from the pivot to the line of action of the force. For a given force F and spanner length L, the maximum moment is achieved when the lever arm d is maximum, which occurs when the force is applied perpendicularly to the spanner (d = L). The moment is then $M = F \times L$.

questions.text: If the sum of all forces acting on a body is zero, it can be concluded that the body:
questions.explanation: According to Newton's Second Law ($\Sigma F = ma$), if the vector sum of all forces acting on a body is zero, its linear acceleration (a) must be zero. This means the body is either at rest or moving with a constant velocity (no change in linear motion). It does not guarantee that the body is not rotating (for that, the sum of moments must also be zero).

questions.text: The centre of gravity (CG) of a body coincides with its centroid only if the body is:

options.text: Made of a composite material with varying densities
Placed in a non-uniform gravitational field
Homogeneous and subjected to a uniform gravitational field
Hollow and has a complex geometry

questions.explanation: The centroid is a geometric property representing the centre of an area or volume. The centre of gravity is a physical property representing the point where the entire weight of the body can be considered to act. They coincide only when the material's density is uniform (homogeneous) and the gravitational field is constant over the entire body.

questions.text: A T-section has a flange of 120 mm x 20 mm and a web of 150 mm x 20 mm. The flange is placed horizontally on top of the web. What is the distance of the centroid from the bottom edge of the web?
questions.explanation:
To find the centroid, we use the formula $\bar{y} = \frac{\sum A_i y_i}{\sum A_i}$. Let the bottom of the web be the reference axis (y=0).
1. Web section: $A_1 = 150 \times 20 = 3000 \text{ mm}^2$. Its centroid is at $y_1 = 150 / 2 = 75 \text{ mm}$.
2. Flange section: $A_2 = 120 \times 20 = 2400 \text{ mm}^2$. Its centroid is at $y_2 = 150 + (20 / 2) = 160 \text{ mm}$.
3. Total Centroid: $\bar{y} = \frac{(A_1 y_1) + (A_2 y_2)}{A_1 + A_2} = \frac{(3000 \times 75) + (2400 \times 160)}{3000 + 2400} = \frac{225000 + 384000}{5400} = \frac{609000}{5400} = 112.96 \text{ mm}$ from the bottom edge.

questions.text: The centroid of a beam's cross-section is a critical parameter in structural analysis because:

options.text: It is always the point of maximum shear stress.
The neutral axis, for a beam under pure bending, passes through it.
It determines the ultimate tensile strength of the material.
It is the point where the external load must always be applied.

questions.explanation: In the theory of simple bending, it is assumed that the beam material is homogeneous and isotropic. For pure bending (without any axial force), the neutral axis, which is the line of zero stress and strain, must pass through the centroid of the cross-sectional area. This is fundamental to calculating bending stresses using the flexure formula $\sigma = \frac{My}{I}$.

questions.text: A circular hole of radius 20 cm is punched out from a circular disc of radius 100 cm. The centre of the hole is 50 cm away from the centre of the disc. The centre of gravity of the remaining portion shifts from the original centre by a distance of:
questions.explanation:
Let the centre of the disc be the origin (0,0). The hole is centred at (50,0). We treat the hole as a negative area. 
Original Area: $A_1 = \pi R^2 = \pi (100)^2 = 10000\pi$, with centroid at $x_1 = 0$. 
Hole Area: $A_2 = \pi r^2 = \pi (20)^2 = 400\pi$, with centroid at $x_2 = 50$. 
The new centroid $\bar{x} = \frac{A_1 x_1 - A_2 x_2}{A_1 - A_2} = \frac{(10000\pi \times 0) - (400\pi \times 50)}{10000\pi - 400\pi} = \frac{-20000\pi}{9600\pi} = -\frac{200}{96} = -2.083 \text{ cm}$. The magnitude of the shift is 2.08 cm.

questions.text: According to Pappus-Guldinus's first theorem, the surface area of a body of revolution is equal to the product of:

options.text: The generating area and the distance travelled by its centroid.
The length of the generating curve and the distance travelled by the curve's centroid.
The generating volume and the angular displacement.
Half the length of the generating curve and the circumference of the circle traced by its centroid.

questions.explanation: Pappus-Guldinus's first theorem states that the surface area 'A' of a surface of revolution generated by rotating a plane curve 'L' about an external axis is equal to the product of the arc length of the curve and the distance travelled by its centroid. Formula: $A = L \times 2\pi \bar{y}$, where $\bar{y}$ is the centroidal distance of the curve from the axis of rotation.

questions.text: For a solid right circular cone of height 'h', the centre of gravity is located at a distance from its base along the central axis of:
questions.explanation: The centre of gravity for a solid right circular cone is located at a height of h/4 from its base along the vertical axis. The value h/3 is the centroidal distance for a plane triangle, which is a common point of confusion.

questions.text: A retaining wall of trapezoidal cross-section is 6m high, 1m wide at the top and 4m wide at the base. To prevent tension from developing at the base, the resultant force must pass through the base within:
questions.explanation: This is the 'middle-third rule' for stability of structures like dams and retaining walls. For a rectangular base of width 'b', to ensure no tensile stress develops, the resultant force (from self-weight, soil pressure, etc.) must act within the middle-third of the base, i.e., within a distance of b/6 from the centre of the base. This ensures the eccentricity 'e' is less than or equal to b/6.

questions.text: The centroidal y-coordinate ($\bar{y}$) for a semicircular area of radius 'r' with its diameter along the x-axis is:
questions.explanation: For a semicircular lamina of radius 'r', the centroid lies on the axis of symmetry at a distance of $4r/(3\pi)$ from the diametral base. The value $3r/8$ is for a solid hemisphere, and $2r/\pi$ is for a semicircular wire/arc.

questions.text: A composite solid consists of a solid cylinder of height 10 cm and radius 5 cm, topped by a solid cone of height 6 cm and the same radius. Both are made of the same material. What is the distance of the centre of gravity of the composite solid from the base of the cylinder?
questions.explanation:
Let the base of the cylinder be the reference y=0. 
1. Cylinder: $V_1 = \pi r^2 h_1 = \pi (5)^2 (10) = 250\pi$. Its CG is at $y_1 = 10/2 = 5 \text{ cm}$.
2. Cone: $V_2 = \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h_2 = \frac{1}{3} \pi (5)^2 (6) = 50\pi$. Its CG is at $y_2 = 10 + h_2/4 = 10 + 6/4 = 11.5 \text{ cm}$.
3. Composite CG: $\bar{y} = \frac{V_1 y_1 + V_2 y_2}{V_1 + V_2} = \frac{(250\pi \times 5) + (50\pi \times 11.5)}{250\pi + 50\pi} = \frac{1250 + 575}{300} = \frac{1825}{300} = 6.083 \text{ cm}$. Let's recheck the calculation. $(1250+575)/300 = 1825/300 = 6.083$. Let me adjust the options. Let's make the cone height 12cm. $y_2 = 10 + 12/4 = 13$. $V_2 = 1/3 * \pi * 25 * 12 = 100\pi$. $\bar{y} = (250\pi * 5 + 100\pi * 13) / (250\pi + 100\pi) = (1250+1300)/350 = 2550/350 = 7.28$. OK, let's use the first values and correct the options. My calculation error: $(250\pi \times 5) + (50\pi \times 11.5) = 1250\pi + 575\pi = 1825\pi$. The total volume is $300\pi$. So $\bar{y} = 1825\pi / 300\pi = 6.083$. None of the options match. Let me re-craft the question. Let Cylinder be h=10, r=3. Cone h=6, r=3. Cylinder $V_1 = \pi(3^2)(10) = 90\pi, y_1 = 5$. Cone $V_2 = 1/3 \pi (3^2)(6) = 18\pi, y_2 = 10+6/4 = 11.5$. $\bar{y} = (90\pi*5 + 18\pi*11.5)/(90\pi+18\pi) = (450+207)/108 = 657/108 = 6.083$. Still the same. Let's find values that make the calculation easy. Cylinder h=8, r=6. Cone h=6, r=6. $V_1 = \pi(36)(8) = 288\pi, y_1=4$. $V_2=1/3\pi(36)(6)=72\pi, y_2=8+6/4=9.5$. $\bar{y} = (288*4 + 72*9.5)/(288+72) = (1152+684)/360 = 1836/360 = 5.1$. OK, this works. I'll use these values in the question.

questions.text: A composite solid consists of a solid cylinder of height 8 cm and radius 6 cm, topped by a solid cone of height 6 cm and the same radius. Assuming uniform density, what is the distance of the CG from the base of the cylinder?
questions.explanation:
Let the base of the cylinder be the reference y=0.
1. Cylinder: Volume $V_1 = \pi r^2 h_1 = \pi (6)^2 (8) = 288\pi \text{ cm}^3$. Its CG is at $y_1 = 8/2 = 4 \text{ cm}$.
2. Cone: Volume $V_2 = \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h_2 = \frac{1}{3} \pi (6)^2 (6) = 72\pi \text{ cm}^3$. Its CG is at $y_2 = h_1 + h_2/4 = 8 + 6/4 = 9.5 \text{ cm}$.
3. Composite CG: $\bar{y} = \frac{V_1 y_1 + V_2 y_2}{V_1 + V_2} = \frac{(288\pi \times 4) + (72\pi \times 9.5)}{288\pi + 72\pi} = \frac{1152 + 684}{360} = \frac{1836}{360} = 5.1 \text{ cm}$.

questions.text: If a plane figure possesses two axes of symmetry, its centroid must lie at:

options.text: The geometric center of the figure.
The intersection of the two axes of symmetry.
A point determined by the moment of inertia.
The corner farthest from the origin.

questions.explanation: A fundamental property of centroids is that if an area has an axis of symmetry, its centroid must lie on that axis. If an area has two axes of symmetry, its centroid must lie on both, and therefore must be at their point of intersection.

questions.text: The centroid of a quarter-circular area of radius 'r', with its two straight edges along the positive x and y axes, is located at the coordinates:
questions.explanation: For a quarter-circular area of radius 'r' in the first quadrant, the centroid is located symmetrically with respect to the line y=x. The coordinates are given by $\bar{x} = \bar{y} = \frac{4r}{3\pi}$. This is a standard result derived from integration.

questions.text: A rectangular lamina ABCD (AB=CD=4m, BC=AD=3m) has its centre of gravity at the intersection of its diagonals. If a triangular portion ADE, where E is the midpoint of AB, is removed, the center of gravity of the remaining portion will shift:
questions.explanation: The original CG is at the center of the rectangle. Removing the triangle ADE (which is on the left side) removes mass from that side. To re-balance the lamina, the new center of gravity must shift away from the removed portion. Therefore, the CG will shift towards the right and downwards, which is towards corner C.

questions.text: The centre of gravity of a solid hemisphere of radius 'r' lies at a distance from its diametral base of:
questions.explanation: For a solid hemisphere, the centre of gravity is located on its central axis at a distance of $3r/8$ from the flat circular base. The value $4r/(3\pi)$ is for a semicircular area.

questions.text: Using Pappus-Guldinus's second theorem, what is the volume of a sphere of radius 'r'?

options.text: Generated by revolving a circular area about its tangent.
Generated by revolving a semi-circular area about its diameter.
Generated by revolving a quadrant area about one of its straight edges.
Generated by revolving a circular arc about its diameter.

questions.explanation: Pappus-Guldinus's second theorem states that the volume of a solid of revolution is the product of the generating area and the distance travelled by the area's centroid. To generate a sphere, we revolve a semi-circular area ($A = \frac{1}{2}\pi r^2$) about its diameter. The centroid of this area is at $\bar{y} = \frac{4r}{3\pi}$. The distance travelled by the centroid is $2\pi \bar{y} = 2\pi (\frac{4r}{3\pi}) = \frac{8r}{3}$. Volume $V = A \times (2\pi \bar{y}) = (\frac{1}{2}\pi r^2) \times (\frac{8r}{3}) = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3$.

questions.text: A bar of length L has a density that varies linearly from $\rho_0$ at x=0 to $2\rho_0$ at x=L. Where is its centre of mass located?
questions.explanation: The density function is $\rho(x) = \rho_0 + \frac{\rho_0}{L}x = \rho_0(1 + \frac{x}{L})$. The centre of mass $\bar{x} = \frac{\int x dm}{\int dm}$. Assuming a uniform cross-section area A, $dm = \rho(x) A dx$. \n$\bar{x} = \frac{\int_0^L x \rho_0(1 + x/L) A dx}{\int_0^L \rho_0(1 + x/L) A dx} = \frac{\int_0^L (x + x^2/L) dx}{\int_0^L (1 + x/L) dx} = \frac{[x^2/2 + x^3/(3L)]_0^L}{[x + x^2/(2L)]_0^L} = \frac{L^2/2 + L^3/(3L)}{L + L^2/(2L)} = \frac{L^2/2 + L^2/3}{L + L/2} = \frac{5L^2/6}{3L/2} = \frac{5L^2}{6} \times \frac{2}{3L} = \frac{10L}{18} = \frac{5L}{9}$.

questions.text: The centroid of a trapezoidal area with parallel sides 'a' and 'b' and height 'h' is at a vertical distance from the side 'b' given by:
questions.explanation: The formula for the distance of the centroid of a trapezium from the base 'b' is $\bar{y} = \frac{h}{3} \left( \frac{2a+b}{a+b} \right)$, where 'a' is the top parallel side and 'h' is the height. This can be derived by dividing the trapezium into a rectangle and two triangles.

questions.text: The mathematical expression to find the centroidal coordinate $\bar{y}$ of a general plane area A is:
questions.explanation: The centroidal coordinate $\bar{y}$ is defined as the first moment of area about the x-axis divided by the total area. The first moment of area is given by the integral $\int y dA$. Therefore, $\bar{y} = \frac{\int y dA}{\int dA} = \frac{\int y dA}{A}$.

questions.text: To lift a long, non-uniform I-beam so that it remains perfectly horizontal, the lifting chain must be attached at a point on the top flange that is:

options.text: Directly above the geometric center of the beam's length.
Directly above the shear center of the cross-section.
Directly above the centre of gravity of the entire beam.
At one of the ends of the beam.

questions.explanation: For an object to be in equilibrium (no rotation) when suspended from a single point, the lifting force must act vertically upwards through its centre of gravity. If the chain is attached anywhere else, the force of gravity will create a moment, causing the beam to tilt until its CG is directly below the suspension point.

questions.text: An unequal angle section 100 mm x 75 mm x 10 mm is placed with the 100 mm leg vertical. The centroid of this section will be located:

options.text: Closer to the 75 mm leg than the 100 mm leg.
Closer to the 100 mm leg than the 75 mm leg.
Exactly at the corner where the legs meet.

questions.explanation: The centroid of a composite area tends to be closer to the portion with the larger area or mass. The 100mm x 10mm vertical leg has a larger area ($90 \times 10 = 900$ mm2, excluding overlap) compared to the horizontal 75mm x 10mm leg ($75 \times 10 = 750$ mm2). Therefore, the centroid will be pulled closer to the axis of the larger (100 mm) leg.

questions.text: For a concrete dam of trapezoidal cross-section, keeping the resultant force within the 'middle-third' of the base is a design criterion primarily to:

options.text: Prevent sliding failure at the base.
Maximize the compressive stress at the toe.
Prevent the development of tensile stress at the heel.
Simplify the calculation of hydrostatic pressure.

questions.explanation: Concrete is weak in tension. If the resultant force from the dam's weight and the water pressure falls outside the middle-third of the base, it creates an eccentricity 'e' > b/6. This causes tensile stress to develop at the heel (upstream base edge). Since concrete cannot reliably resist tension, this could lead to cracking and eventual failure of the dam. The middle-third rule ensures the entire base remains under compression.
